stem: The nurse is reviewing the electronic health record (EHR) of four infants during their well-child visits. Based on the assessment findings, match each infant with the most likely developmental age range.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00 SBAR for patient A. Situation: Patient A is a 6-month-old male presenting for a well-child visit. Background: Mother reports patient was born at term with no complications. He has been meeting developmental milestones as expected until now. Assessment: Upon examination, patient A does not roll over independently. Recommendations: Discuss developmental expectations with the mother and schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 month.

08:30 SBAR for patient B. Situation: Patient B is an 18-month-old female presenting for a well-child visit. Background: Patient B was born prematurely at 32 weeks gestation. She has been receiving early intervention services. Assessment: Patient B walks independently but uses a wide-based gait. She speaks approximately 5-10 words. Recommendations: Continue with current therapy and monitor progress.

09:00 SBAR for patient C. Situation: Patient C is a 12-month-old male presenting for a well-child visit. Background: Patient C was born at term with no complications. Assessment: Patient C pulls to stand and cruises along furniture. He babbles and says 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically. Recommendations: Encourage continued development and schedule routine 15-month follow up.

09:30 SBAR for patient D. Situation: Patient D is an 6-month-old female presenting for a well-child visit. Background: Patient D was born at term with no complications. Assessment: Patient D sits unsupported, transfers objects hand-to-hand, and babbles. Recommendations: Reassure mother of normal development. Schedule routine 9-month follow up.

rows.text: Patient A: Does not roll over independently.
Patient B: Walks with wide-based gait, speaks 5-10 words.
Patient C: Pulls to stand, cruises, babbles, says 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically.
Patient D: Sits unsupported, transfers objects hand-to-hand, babbles.

rationale.correct: Matching milestones to age ranges involves understanding the expected progression of physical and cognitive development in infants. At 6 months, infants typically roll over, sit with support, and begin transferring objects. At 12 months, they pull to stand, cruise, and may say a few words. By 18 months, toddlers walk independently (though gait may still be developing) and have a vocabulary of at least several words.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect age range assignments indicate a misunderstanding of typical developmental progressions. For example, assigning a child who is not rolling over to the 12-month category is incorrect because rolling over is expected much earlier. Assigning a child walking independently with a limited vocabulary to the 6-month category is also incorrect, as walking and more advanced language skills are expected later.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient A: Does not roll over independently.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Rolling over is typically achieved by 6 months. Patient A's inability to roll over at 6 months suggests a need for further assessment and potential intervention, but is still within the range of normal for 6 months if other milestones are met.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient B: Walks with wide-based gait, speaks 5-10 words.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Walking independently with a wide-based gait and speaking 5-10 words is characteristic of the 18-month developmental stage.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient C: Pulls to stand, cruises, babbles, says 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Pulling to stand, cruising, and babbling with nonspecific 'mama' and 'dada' are typical milestones for a 12-month-old infant.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient D: Sits unsupported, transfers objects hand-to-hand, babbles.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Sitting unsupported, transferring objects hand-to-hand, and babbling are expected milestones for a 6-month-old infant.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones are guidelines, and variations can occur. Prematurity should be considered when assessing milestones.
Regular monitoring and early intervention are crucial for children with developmental delays.
Always consider the whole picture. A single delayed milestone may not be significant if other milestones are met.

questionTrap.trap: Many students memorize milestones without understanding the range of normal. They may rigidly assign a child to an age range based on a single milestone without considering others.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on understanding the general trends in development and consider multiple milestones together. Remember that milestones are ranges, not fixed points.

mnemonic.title: SMART Milestones
mnemonic.expansion: S - Social/Emotional, M - Motor (Gross & Fine), A - Adaptive, R - Receptive Language, T - Talkative Language. Assess each domain to accurately determine developmental age.
